Situation1: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I’ve been saving for years, every spare ringgit tucked away with the hope of finally performing Hajj. This year, my friends are going, and my name is on the list. The excitement in our community is palpable; everyone expects me to join, to fulfill this pillar of my faith now that I have the means. But the election falls on the same week. As a citizen, I’m expected to vote, to show up with my identification and play my part in shaping our country’s future. The polling station is nearby, and I have all the required IDs, but the timing is tight. If I leave for Hajj, I might miss my chance to vote. If I stay to vote, I might lose my spot for Hajj, and who knows when I’ll get another chance? My heart aches as I weigh the expectations—my faith pulling me one way, my civic duty the other. I sit at my desk, passport and voting card in hand, torn between two worlds, unable to move.
